Issues.Title: bug(ivy): runtime error for unknown element even with NO_ERRORS_SCHEMA
Issues.Body:
The ivy runtime throws an error if there is an unknown element, even if the NgModule contains the `NO_ERRORS_SCHEMA`. See the reproduction here: ``` git clone https://github.com/petebacondarwin/ivy-schema-test && cd ivy-schema-test && npm i && npm start -o ``` Open console in the browser to see the error: ``` core.js:6068 ERROR Error: 'some-element' is not a known element: 1. If 'some-element' is an Angular component, then verify that it is part of this module. 2. If 'some-element' is a Web Component then add 'CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA' to the '@NgModule.schemas' of this component to suppress this message. at validateElement (core.js:23517) at ɵɵelementStart (core.js:23323) at Module.ɵɵelement (core.js:23389) at AppComponent_Template (app.component.html:2) at executeTemplate (core.js:13880) at renderView (core.js:13682) at renderComponent (core.js:15111) at renderChildComponents (core.js:13484) at renderView (core.js:13708) at ComponentFactory$1.create (core.js:34077) ``` The `AppComponent` template looks like: ```html
``` but the `AppModule` has the `NO_ERRORS_SCHEMA`: ```ts @NgModule({ declarations: [ AppComponent ], imports: [ BrowserModule ], providers: [], schemas: [NO_ERRORS_SCHEMA], bootstrap: [AppComponent] }) export class AppModule { } ``` Note that if you remove the `NO_ERRORS_SCHEMA` then the build fails, as expected, during AOT compile time. This looks like a regression that was introduced by https://github.com/angular/angular/commit/c83f5013bfb0182dc653d7e5d8a1750e09ea50e9
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(ivy): runtime error for unknown element even with NO_ERRORS_SCHEMA" (#33976)

Issues.Title: fix(ngcc): do not crash on packages that specify typings as an array
Issues.Body:
In a package.json file, the "typings" or "types" field could be an array
of typings files. ngcc would previously crash unexpectedly for such
packages, as it assumed that the typings field would be a string. This
commit lets ngcc skip over such packages, as having multiple typing
entry-points is not supported for Angular packages so it is safe to
ignore them.

Fixes #33646
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ngcc): do not crash on packages that specify typings as an array" (#33973)

Issues.Title: HttpClient generic methods should expect text responseType when generic type is number/string/boolean
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 feature request

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for @angular/http

### Description
The functionality of HttpClient.get<T>/.post<T> etc is unintuitive when using generic type number/string/boolean.

Generics are typically intended to strongly type a class/function, and if there's an ungeneric version typically it's expected to act the same way except without strong typing. However HttpClient does not act that way which may cause unexpected behavior.

Specifically while JSON (or another syntax) would clearly be needed to parse complex objects out of an API, simple types like string, boolean, and number might be intuitively expected to be parsed as text, not json.

Issue #18672 showcases the confusion possible as does this stackoverflow post: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49771603/types-of-property-responsetype-are-incompatible

### Describe the solution you'd like
When these types are specified, HttpClient should default to "text" responseType option. Normally the generic version of these functions always expects JSON text. A user can still override the responseType back to "json" for the old behavior to shim old code.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
This solution could potentially cause breaking changes. number and boolean types would likely be unaffected as json and text forms of these types are identical. However string types are the general problem. That said, are there really any APIs that return a quoted string for Angular to parse as JSON? Who knows...

Other alternative is to maintain this behavior. The current documentation at https://angular.io/guide/http#requesting-non-json-data covers this case but perhaps could be expanded on to explicitly warn that use of the generic versions of these functions requires the API to return JSON. Currently it says there "is no need" to use it for string types which implies it might still work when it doesn't.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "HttpClient generic methods should expect text responseType when generic type is number/string/boolean" (#33972)

Issues.Title: Size tracking improvements
Issues.Body:
*ci: tighten code owners for size tracking*

It will be easier to track regressions in size if fewer people
are approving size diffs in PRs. That way, we will have a few
people that have a fuller picture of where size changes are
coming from.
 
*ci: tighten size threshold to 1% or 500 bytes*

The size diff threshold of 1% has proven to be too lenient for us
to catch size regressions in AIO. Since the AIO main bundle is
between 400-500 KB, a size regression must be between 4-5 KB before
it will cause the tests to fail. As a result, we may merge many
changes with smaller regressions of a few KB before the size test
eventually lets us know that the number has increased. The hope is
that lowering the threshold will help us catch the smaller
regressions during code review and prevent the size tests failing at
a random later time when someone catches the size "hot potato".

---

![Screen Shot 2019-11-21 at 5 17 57 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3871688/69390112-0ad1eb80-0c83-11ea-9818-7d15c0f237d9.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Size tracking improvements" (#33969)

Issues.Title: The Date pipe returns incorrect week numbers
Issues.Body:
<!--🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅

Oh hi there! 😄

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅-->
Hi, I believe I've come across a bug in the date parsing. I haven't seen any indications that this is expected behavior, so I'm opening an issue here.

# 🐞 bug report

### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: --> The issue is caused by package @angular/common: ^6.1.9


### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
<!-- ✍️--> Not that I've seen.


### Description

<!-- ✍️--> 
The Date pipe has some unexpected behavior when it comes to weeks. A week is defined as a period of exactly 7 days (according to Wikipedia), and according to ISO 8601, the first week of a year is the week containing the first Thursday of the year.


By these rules, 2019 has 52 weeks, and 2020 has 53 weeks.


E.g. the first week of 2020 is the week from 30th of December to the 5th of January. 
The Date pipe returns the period from December 29th to December 31st as week 53, and January 1st of 2020 as week 1. 


The date parsing has an extra week in 2019, which has 3 days, which seems like unexpected behavior.

## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction

-->
<!-- ✍️--> https://angular-issue-repro2-ycvycu.stackblitz.io


```js
{{ '2019-12-29T00:00:00' | date:'w' }}
```

Issues.Title: docs: update injectable migration guide to reflect latest schematic changes
Issues.Body:
Since we created the migration guide for the `missing-injectable` schematic, the schematic
changed in various ways. e.g. the migration no longer migrates classes passed to `useExisting`

Additionally the migration has been expanded to handle another Ivy breaking change where
providers like `{provide: X}` will be intepreted as `{provide: X, useClass: X}`. This pattern should
be documented in the migration guide.

Issues.Body:
With Angular CLI version 9 RC 3 we can run a single migration for a package using the name of the migration schematic.

We need to pass the schematic name as a value to the `migrate-only` option.
Ex:

```
ng update @angular/core --migrate-only migration-v9-undecorated-classes-with-di
```

Issues.Title: ci: use more descriptive names for published build artifacts
Issues.Body:
In efbbae5a4, the `publish_packages_as_artifacts` CircleCI job was created to publish the build artifacts of PR builds on CI. In a8f4f14bd, its scope was expanded to also publish build artifacts on non-PR builds.

The published artifacts names are constructed based on the PR number (e.g. include `-pr12345-`), so on non-PR builds the names do not reflect the source branch (instead, they include `-prfalse-`).

This commit fixes this by using the current branch name. For example, artifact names for the `master` or `9.0.x` branch will include `-master-` and `-9.0.x-` respectively (instead of `-prfalse-`).
(NOTE: For PRs, where branch name is `pull/12345`, the branch name is transformed to `pr12345`.)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "ci: use more descriptive names for published build artifacts" (#33957)

Issues.Title: ngSwitchCase no longer accepts multiple values
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 feature request

### Relevant Package

@angular/common

### Description

Upgrading to Angular 2 has a feature regression, when multiple match values for ngSwitchCase are supported.

https://docs.angularjs.org/api/ng/directive/ngSwitch 

This was raised in https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/12174 but it was closed and locked due to old issue bad new issue good.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Angular 1 uses string tokenization and ngSwitchWhenSeparator,

I however prefer ngSwitchCases direction that accepts a list of values to match.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Copy-paste.

Manually create common template definition and instantiate it.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ngSwitchCase no longer accepts multiple values" (#33953)

# 🐞 Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [ ] new

- [ ] serve

### Is this a regression?

No.

### Description

Cannot upgrade to 9.0.0.rc.3 due circular requirements.
When I run `ng update` I get an error:

```
Error: The ngcc compiler has changed since the last ngcc build.
Please remove "/home/harry/Projects/.../users-app/node_modules" and try again.
```

Now I delete `node_modules` and try again, I get the following error:

```
Package '@angular/cli' is not a dependency.
```

If I run `npm i ` and run `ng update` again, I get the same error again:

```
Error: The ngcc compiler has changed since the last ngcc build.
Please remove "/home/harry/Projects/.../users-app/node_modules" and try again.
```

I haven't found a way for workaround for this circular requirements.


## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction

I tried many different variations, but none worked. This is one example:

```
rm -rf node_modules
npm i
ng update --force @angular/cli@next @angular/core@next
```

Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] build ### Is this a regression? I've updated from angular cli 8.2.2 to 8.3.19. I'm experiencing extremely slow es5 generation, more than 40min, on a 2min es2015 build project. The command is the default `ng build --prod` Before: es2015: Date: 2019-11-19T15:25:55.426Z - Hash: 6c35a01295520babc484 - Time: 148057ms es5: Date: 2019-11-19T15:28:43.552Z - Hash: 0fd8da57b70a110eb175 - Time: 167641ms

After: Date: 2019-11-19T16:28:22.217Z - Hash: 5d634a67585b345c8c54 - Time: 2624975ms
Output of ng --version ``` $ ng --version _ _ ____ _ ___ / \ _ __ __ _ _ _| | __ _ _ __ / ___| | |_ _| / △ \ | '_ \ / _` | | | | |/ _` | '__| | | | | | | / ___ \| | | | (_| | |_| | | (_| | | | |___| |___ | | /_/ \_\_| |_|\__, |\__,_|_|\__,_|_| \____|_____|___| |___/ Angular CLI: 8.3.19 Node: 10.16.3 OS: linux x64 Angular: 8.2.14 ... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms ... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic ... router Package Version ----------------------------------------------------------- @angular-devkit/architect 0.803.19 @angular-devkit/build-angular 0.803.19 @angular-devkit/build-optimizer 0.803.19 @angular-devkit/build-webpack 0.803.19 @angular-devkit/core 8.3.19 @angular-devkit/schematics 8.3.19 @angular/cdk 8.2.3 @angular/cli 8.3.19 @angular/material 8.2.3 @ngtools/webpack 8.3.19 @schematics/angular 8.3.19 @schematics/update 0.803.19 rxjs 6.5.3 typescript 3.5.3 webpack 4.39.2 ```
### Description I've tried disabling the es5 generation, by changing the `browserslist` file and the compilation time comparable with the previous version Date: 2019-11-19T20:25:10.213Z - Hash: fbbc4140d56be9279818 - Time: 147941ms Also visually the compilation of the es2015 build finishes, the files as generated in about 2 minutes, then it sits in `Generating ES5 bundles for differential loading...` for about to 40 minutes. I don't think it's a node memory related problem since the process that takes 40 minutes uses about 100MB of ram ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction I cannot share the project code, these are the dependencies I'm using.

Issues.Title: Support for CLI extension
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ x] build
- [x ] serve
- [x ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ x] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description

Maybe somebody already asked this but are there any plans in terms of extensibility of CLI build tasks? 


1. I understand right now the recomended way to extend cli is to write schematics to create some custom generate command. Or even override existing ones like some of the cli are doing it.
2. You are also able to use `builder API` to really change behavior or create new for the existing commands (build, serve, test,..)
3. if I want to extends existing build process, then I can extends `browser build` `export default createBuilder` where I can call existinb fn `buildWebpackBrowser as executeBrowserBuilder`, and then do some my own logic

- But what I am strugling with or I dont see a solution, how do I easily extend and alter building process of existing application that might already be using some builder API. 

Current solution does not scale, as you can extend `builder API` and replace application's configuration for your builder, but this would not work if they are already using some custom builder API. So replace is not really an option. 

What you need some Injection points, to be able to register your tasks before, after each task. I know ngx-build-plus is trying to do something similar, but again if we use ngx-build-plus and project has already some builder it will not work. 

Like Maven, Gradle,....

Any pointers ?






### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ✍️--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ✍️--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): properly process es2016+ targets with differential loading
Issues.Body:
A target of es2015 was previously assumed when using differential loading.  This could result in erroneously downleveling an es2016+ output file instead of generating a new es5 output file.

Closes #15610

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): resolve lazy route Angular package from project base
Issues.Body:
The plugin's package could technically be installed outside of the location containing the Angular dependencies and/or the project root.  This is particularly relevant for `pnpm` or `yarn pnp` (even though the later is not yet supported) since they strictly enforce package presence and versioning.

Closes #16219

Issues.Title: ng lint succeeds when tslint fails, and other default linting misconfiguration (vscode)
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [x] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? No, this never worked AFAIK. ### Description tslint and ng lint should behave the same. In general, ng build and ng serve should fail when code that tslint shall consider as {"severity": "error"} is encountered. I lost 3 hours first isolating a bug caused by a shadowed variable, then trying to make my build always fail and my IDE report "no-shadowed-variable" as an error. After I put the line ``` "no-shadowed-variable": {"severity": "error"} ``` in the ./tsconfig.json file, all my tools should recognize and report this error always. Currently they don't. ng lint is one of them ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction 

ng new tslint-errors-ng-vscode
Then append to app.component.ts the following 

function f(key: string) {
    const o = {hello: 0};
    Object.keys(o).forEach((key: string) => {console.log(key)});
}

f("world")
This code demonstrates shadowing. Does it do what we want? We should probably have used a different variable name. Let's assume we had a bug caused by shadowing. Now we want to make sure that never happens again, so we want the build to fail if we ever rely on shadowing anywhere. So we put in tslint.json under rules: ``` "no-shadowed-variable": {"severity": "error"} ``` But damn it: Our IDE still shows it as a warning: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2378665/69176436-0207db00-0b06-11ea-8cc4-0eb7d439e684.png) aha, the vscode team messed up: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-typescript-tslint-plugin/issues/122 so we configure in settings json "tslint.alwaysShowRuleFailuresAsWarnings": false F*** now everything is an error: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2378665/69176505-1e0b7c80-0b06-11ea-927d-20fcf80f030f.png) Aha, the angular team messed up: The didn't put any "defaultSeverity" in ./tslint.json so let's do that: ``` "defaultSeverity": "warning" ``` After restarting the IDE (because we live in the fantastic time where some changes have immediate effect and some require a restart and no one know which require a restart...) it behaves properly ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2378665/69176641-6460db80-0b06-11ea-99d2-bb71ef71704b.png) Now lets see the CLI: ``` tslint --project . --quiet ``` properly reports only the ERRORs ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2378665/69176711-8b1f1200-0b06-11ea-96cc-6fcc69788a72.png) ``` ng lint ``` detects the error, but happily reports that "All files pass linting.". **Clearly a BUG.** ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2378665/69176820-bc97dd80-0b06-11ea-8e33-d1bf75f99cc7.png) ng serve succeeds - **arguably it should treat linting errors just as much as errors as typechecking errors!** **ng build succeeds - yay, "errors" in tslint.json officially means nothing to angular :(** ## 🔥 Exception or Error 

All files pass linting.
When there is a linting ERROR. ## 🌍 Your Environment 


     _                      _                 ____ _     ___
    / \   _ __   __ _ _   _| | __ _ _ __     / ___| |   |_ _|
   / △ \ | '_ \ / _` | | | | |/ _` | '__|   | |   | |    | |
  / ___ \| | | | (_| | |_| | | (_| | |      | |___| |___ | |
 /_/   \_\_| |_|\__, |\__,_|_|\__,_|_|       \____|_____|___|
                |___/

Node: 11.13.0
OS: win32 x64

Issues.Title: build: enable bazel node modules symlinking [resubmit w/ fixes]
Issues.Body:
Resubmit with fixes for the release building failures.

The symlinking allowed us use caching for node_modules. This meant that we needed
to rework how we apply postinstall patches to:

*  Still throw if something no longer applies (i.e. when updating Angular)
* To not throw if yarn runs on node_modules  already patched/restored from cache.

To do this, we implemented something called "marker files" that can be used to
determine if a file has been patched or not. Unfortunately I didn't realize that we
have multiple individual patches for the same file, so the first patch edit created the
marker, and followed patches for the same file got skipped.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: enable bazel node modules symlinking [resubmit w/ fixes]" (#17776)

Issues.Title: fix(drag-drop): position reset if viewport is resized while boundary is invisible
Issues.Body:
If a dragged item is inside a boundary, we update its position on window resize to ensure that it stays inside the boundary. If a resize event happens while the boundary is hidden, we end up resetting the user's position unintentionally. These changes add a check that prevents the position from changing if the elements are hidden.

Fixes #17750.

Issues.Title: mat-select poorly handles "space" when performing typeahead
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

repro: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-hr8bq9

Steps to reproduce issue 1:
1. Focus on select with it closed
2. Type "United K"
3. When the space character is typed the select is opened

Steps to reproduce issue 2:
1. Open select
2. Type "United K"
3. When the space character is typed the select is closed and "United States" is selected
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
Space does not open/close the select when typeahead is being performed. " " character should be treated as part of the typeahead as long as the debounce time has not yet cleared.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
Space always opens the select when closed and always closes the select and selects an option when it is open.

#### Environment

- Angular:
- CDK/Material:
- Browser(s):
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):

Issues.Title: schematics(update): v9 migration fails due to chalk
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://github.com/parys/MyLFC/tree/poc/angular9/src/MyLiverpool.Web.WebApiNext/ClientApp

Steps to reproduce:
1. Remove `postinstall` script and update core and universal ([commit](https://github.com/Splaktar/MyLFC/commit/28d01bcb2c33e4402afb7aaa33d847e6a7819371))
2. Run `ng update @angular/material --migrate-only --from 8 --to 9`

```sh
** Executing migrations of package '@angular/material' **
❯ Updates Angular Material to v9
Cannot read property 'yellow' of undefined
✖ Migration failed. See above for further details.
```
3. `npm i --save-dev chalk` (installs `3.0.0`)
4. Run `ng update @angular/material --migrate-only --from 8 --to 9`

```sh
** Executing migrations of package '@angular/material' **
❯ Updates Angular Material to v9
Cannot read property 'yellow' of undefined
✖ Migration failed. See above for further details.
```
5. `npm i --save-dev chalk@2.4.2` ([commit](https://github.com/Splaktar/MyLFC/commit/985697b627e344cdc4ec0d9b67c6f668dddce1b8))
6. Run `ng update @angular/material --migrate-only --from 8 --to 9`
7. Successful update
 
#### Expected Behavior
`chalk` should not be required as a dev or peer dependency. Angular CLI builders currently appear to use `2.4.2`.
The migration should succeed.

#### Actual Behavior
Exception as indicated above.

#### Environment

- Angular: 9.0.0-rc.3
- CDK/Material: 9.0.0-rc.2
- Browser(s): N/A
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS Catalina

Fixes #17761.

Issues.Title: Calling MatListItem#focus() does not update the MatMenu's focusKeyManager's active item
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Repro: https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-svmexm

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open a menu
2. Programatically focus some mat-menu-item other than the first one (in the stackblitz repro above, the third mat-menu-item, "C" is focused, due to the onOpen() method in AppComponent, which calls the third mat-menu-item's `focus` method.)
3. Press the down arrow key (note: a similar variant applies to the up arrow case.)
  
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

The next mat-list-item, "D", should be focused.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

The second mat-list-item, "B", is focused.

#### Analysis

This is happening because the mat menu's FocusKeyManager still thinks the first mat menu item is the active item, even thought we programatically focused a different mat-menu-item. Since mat menu's key manager is private / not exposed to downstream developers, I don't think there's a way to address it currently without a change to Angular Material.

#### Some possible solutions

* Update the MatMenuItem#focus method to also update the mat menu's active item at the same time
* Expose the mat menu's key manager so downstream developers can call its setActiveItem method.
* Add to the mat menu public API a method to set the active item key manager's active item

#### Environment

- Angular: 8
- CDK/Material: 8
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Ubuntu
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Calling MatListItem#focus() does not update the MatMenu's focusKeyManager's active item" (#17761)

Issues.Title: Drag and Drop: If view port changes to have a smaller width, element could be off screen
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/angular/mjmpdxjmmee?file=src%2Fapp%2Fcdk-drag-drop-overview-example.ts


![Example](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1402918/69269458-acc7da00-0b96-11ea-9d23-8328bb54f495.gif)
Above is an example from a project I am working on.

Steps to reproduce:
1.  Drag an element to the far right side of the screen.
2.  Resize view port
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

The parent container scales and the draggable elements squeeze to fit.


#### Actual Behavior

The draggable element is off screen and can only be accessible through scrolling. Scrolling is fine on a desktop, but for mobile sized screens, it is just too clunky.

#### Environment

- Angular: 9.0.0-rc.2
- CDK/Material: 9.0.0-rc.2
- Browser(s): Chrome, Safari.
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  macOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Drag and Drop: If view port changes to have a smaller width, element could be off screen" (#17759)

Issues.Title: refactor(ng-update): do not copy gesture config if only standard HammerJS events are used
Issues.Body:
Currently the HammerJS v9 migration always copies the gesture config
if HammerJS events are used. This is not necessary for projects where
only _standard_ HammerJS events are used. These events are provided
by the default hammer gesture config that comes with the `HammerModule`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(ng-update): do not copy gesture config if only standard HammerJS events are used" (#17753)

Issues.Title: build: remove schematic tsconfig project references
Issues.Body:
In the past we set up project references for the
Material and CDK schematics. This was necessary
since the Material schematic code referenced the
CDK schematic code through source files, and this
could have caused an invalid file structure in the
release output.

Nowadays, since we use Bazel, the Material schematics
no longer refer to the source files of the CDK schematics,
and this issue is automatically solved. This also fixes IDE's
like WebStorm incorrectly reporting that the CDK schematics
are not built, when working inside the Material schematics.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: remove schematic tsconfig project references" (#17756)

Issues.Title: build: fix missing amd module name for primary entry-point
Issues.Body:
Even though the primary entry-point of Angular Material is empty,
it should still have an AMD module name (similar to the CDK).

A good example is that consumers of Angular Material in a Bazel
project can have the unnamed bundle as input of a target (like
ts_devserver). RequireJS will then throw about an anonymous
module.

Fixes #17720
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: fix missing amd module name for primary entry-point" (#17757)

Issues.Title: refactor: handle stubbed window in SSR checks
Issues.Body:
Based on feedback from @CaerusKaru 

Uses the `isPlatformBrowser` to check whether we're rendering on the server in the `google-maps` and `youtube-player` packages, similarly to what we're doing in the CDK. This handles people stubbing out the `window`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor: handle stubbed window in SSR checks" (#17755)

Issues.Title: cdkDragBoundary is resetting positions of draggable elements when boundary is invisible
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://angular-p8rakh.stackblitz.io

Steps to reproduce:
1.  There are two tabs. Select "**tab-2**". Move around the red proxy/div and set it somewhere different than 0, 0.

2. Move to "**tab-1**". This is a blank-tab but it's enough to reproduce the bug. Now, resize your chrome window (1 pixel is enough).

3. Move back to "**tab-2**" and ... boom! the red proxy/div **has been reset to position 0, 0**!

This actually makes cdkDragBoundary unusable for us since we have a very flexible and rich layout system.

 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

I was expecting the cdkDrag + cdkDragBoundary to exactly work as if "**tab-2**" was always visible: **maintaining the red proxy at its dragged position** (translate3d) **or modify it depending on the available container size**.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

As stated before, the dragged red proxy gets its position reset after a chrome window resize if boundary container is "invisible". 


#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.14
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3
- Browser(s): 78.0.3904.97
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10 Enterprise 1809
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "cdkDragBoundary is resetting positions of draggable elements when boundary is invisible" (#17750)
